responses: When defining the system with multiple iD Tops, consider the following rules: 1) A different role is a separate system; combine iD Tops for EAS with those for sales floor installation is impossible. 2) Within the EAS role, combine all iD Tops into one system, as the Renos platform has a synchronization mechanism for RFID technology. 3) Maximum cable length requirements must be considered; if you exceed them, split the installation into two or more systems.

patterns: What is the recommended height for the OVR?
How should I place the OVRs for optimal performance?
What are the aisle width recommendations for OVRs?
Can you explain the detection distance for RFID?
responses: The recommended height for the OVR is 2.5 m (8.2 ft). A lower OVR height results in a smaller and more controlled RFID field, leading to more stable performance.
It is possible to mount an OVR between 250 cm (8.2 ft) and 350 cm (11.5 ft) height.
We recommend placing the OVRs at an aisle width of 220 cm (7.2 ft) to 250 cm (8.2 ft), depending on the entrance space.

patterns: What are the RFID installation requirements?
How does RFID technology differ from RF technology in installations?
What is the recommended label-free zone for RFID?
Can you explain the tag muting feature?
responses: For RFID installations, it's recommended to have a label-free zone of more than 150 cm (4.9 ft) from the center of the antenna.
RFID technology has different installation requirements compared to RF. The RFID field is less strictly defined, leading to a larger detection area for tags.
The RFID reader's maximum throughput is around 200 tag reads per second. When tags are close together, the reader may be busier, which could impact performance and lead to some tags being muted.
This feature is known as 'Automatic Tag Muting,' where some tags in proximity are muted to allow the reader to monitor others without causing an alarm.

patterns: How do metal surfaces affect RFID installations?
What should be avoided near RFID readers?
Can you explain the impact of metal on detection fields?
What are the installation guidelines for metal surfaces?
responses: Metal surfaces can reflect the RFID field, confusing the Dynamic Beam Steering algorithms and altering the detection field. Avoid placing metallic surfaces near readers.
The front and back areas of the unit must be completely metal-free to ensure optimal performance.
If it's impossible to maintain a metal-free zone due to installation requirements, this may cause false alarms and reduced detection quality.

patterns: What is the function of the Power Inserter?
How many Renos units can connect to a Power Inserter?
What are the specifications for the Power Inserter?
Can I use any Power-over-Ethernet switch with Renos?
responses: The Power Inserter is used to power Renos systems, and a maximum of 5 Renos units can be connected to one Power Inserter for both 230V and 115V configurations.
Please note that you must only use a Nedap Power Inserter to power Renos systems; generic Power-over-Ethernet switches or standalone inserters are not compatible.
It is recommended to connect the Power Inserter to an always-on power socket, which allows for continuous system monitoring and remote firmware updates.
When handling network cables in the system, always disconnect the power cable from the Power Inserter(s) first while ensuring the system is powered off.

patterns: How should the RFID readers be oriented?

responses: All RFID readers must be oriented in the same way due to their orientation sensitivity. An arrow in the product bracket indicates the correct orientation.
If the orientation procedure is not executed correctly, the RFID technology will not function properly.

patterns: What is the cabling procedure for the OVR line?
How do I connect the Renos units?
Can you explain the daisy chain topology for connections?
responses: The OVR line uses a daisy chain topology for cabling. The connections should follow this sequence: 1) A cable from a Power Inserter OUT to a Renos unit IN. 2) From that Renos unit OUT to the next Renos unit IN, and so on.
Ensure that the cabling is implemented properly once the basis placement and orientation are confirmed.

patterns: What type of cable is used for the iSense system?
How should I connect the units on the sales floor?
What are the cable specifications for the iSense system?
Can you explain the termination standards for Ethernet cables?
responses: The iSense units are connected only via an Ethernet cable and should be wired from right to left when standing on the sales floor looking outside the store.
Use UTP Cat5e with a stranded copper core, and a core diameter of 24 AWG (0.51 mm).
Always connect all four pairs of wires using the T568B termination standard or the T568A standard if specifically required.
Never use CCA (copper clad aluminum) or CCS/CCF (copper clad steel) cables.

patterns: What are the T568A and T568B pinout specifications?
Can you explain the differences between T568A and T568B?
How should I wire an Ethernet cable using T568A or T568B?
responses: The T568A and T568B standards are used for terminating Ethernet cables. Below are the pinout specifications:
T568A: 1-Green + White, 2-Green, 3-Orange + White, 4-Blue, 5-Blue + White, 6-Orange, 7-Brown + White, 8-Brown.
T568B (Preferred): 1-Orange + White, 2-Orange, 3-Green + White, 4-Blue, 5-Blue + White, 6-Green, 7-Brown + White, 8-Brown.
When terminating cables, T568B is the preferred standard. Ensure to follow the pin configuration to avoid connectivity issues.

patterns: What is the maximum cable length between a Power Inserter and a Renos unit?

Are there any recommendations for cable connections?
What should I consider about cable lengths in my setup?
responses: The maximum cable length is 80 meters (250 ft) between a Power Inserter and the last Renos unit receiving power from that Power Inserter.
Similarly, the maximum cable length is also 80 meters (250 ft) between Renos units (excluding Power Inserters) and between the first (or last) Renos unit and the WAN connection in the store.
You can use your own preferred connectors, but ensure they're suitable for the cable used and that the correct crimping tool is applied.
It's recommended to place the Power Inserter in the switch room (near a power socket) to allow for proper ethernet cable lengths.
If the cable lengths between two groups exceed approximately 50 meters (164 ft), consider splitting the system into two.

patterns: What do the status LEDs on the Renos unit mean?
Can you explain the LED indicators for the Renos unit?
What is the meaning of the different LED colors and statuses?
How can I check the status of my Renos unit using LEDs?
responses: Here are the status LED explanations for the Renos unit:
1. **Green LED**: On - There is a Renos unit connected to the OUT port of this unit. Off - There is no Renos unit connected.
2. **Blue LED**: Blinking - There is no device connected to the OUT port. On - There is a Power Inserter connected.

3. **Red LED**: On - There is an issue with the power supply at the OUT port (too little current drawn). Blinking - There is an issue with the supply (too much current drawn). Off - No issue with the power supply.
4. **Yellow LED**: Blinking - The operating system on the Renos unit is running. Off - The operating system is not running.
5. **Green LED (storage)**: Blinking - The storage flash is accessed. Off - The storage flash is not accessed.
6. **Green LED (firmware)**: On - The firmware on the Renos unit is running.

patterns: What do the status LEDs on the RFID reader mean?
Can you explain the LED indicators for the RFID reader?
What are the meanings of the different LED colors and statuses for the RFID reader?
How can I check the status of my RFID reader using LEDs?
responses: Here are the status LED explanations for the RFID reader:
1. **Blue LED**: On - The RFID Reader is connected to the Renos firmware. Blinking - The RFID Reader has received a command from the Renos firmware. Off - The RFID reader is NOT connected.
2. **Orange LED**: Blinking slow - The firmware on the RFID Reader is running. Off - The firmware on the RFID reader is NOT running.
3. **Red LED**: On - There is an error with the RFID output.

Please note that if the Renos unit has a firmware error, the rightmost three LEDs (4, 5, and 6) will remain off when powered. This can be resolved via a 'Local - single unit' firmware update, as described in the 'Sense firmware version manual.'

responses: Here are the additional status LED explanations for the RFID reader:
4. **Green LED (RFID output)**: On - The RFID output is active. Blinking - The reader is reading RFID labels. Off - The RFID output is NOT active.
5. **Green LED (power)**: On - The Renos unit powers the RFID reader. Off - The Renos unit does NOT power the RFID reader.
Note: The RFID reader will not be active when the system has not been configured yet. At that point, only the 'firmware running' orange LED will be blinking.

patterns: How do I connect my laptop to the Renos unit?

responses: You can connect your laptop via a Mini-USB cable to the service port on the Renos unit. In the iSense system, you can choose any Renos unit.

responses: During the configuration, you are required to authenticate yourself. The method depends on the availability of Device Management.
1. If the system is connected to Device Management, you can enter your Nedap Retail username and password directly.

2. If the system is not connected to Device Management and you don't have a Nedap Retail authentication software, consider the following options:

   - If that option isn't available, you can use your smartphone.
   - If your smartphone has no internet access, call your main technician for an authentication code.
For more details on obtaining a Nedap Retail username and password, please reach out to support.

If you need clarification while using the wizard, look for the question mark button on the top right corner of each page. Clicking it will provide more information on what's expected on that specific page.

patterns: How do I perform a firmware change on a Renos-based system?
What are the steps to factory reset a Renos-based system?
How can I update the firmware on my Renos unit?
What is the System ID and why do I need it?
responses: It is essential to use the latest firmware version and start new installations with factory default units. Here’s how to perform a firmware update and factory reset:

### Firmware Change
There are four ways to change the firmware version on a Renos-based system:
1. **Local—single unit overwrite**: Insert a USB stick with the correct firmware into the USB port to execute the overwriting.
2. **Local—complete system overwrite**: You can execute this from your laptop during the configuration wizard.
3. **Local - complete system update**: This can also be executed during the configuration wizard.
4. **Device Management update**: This update can be executed via the Device Management service.

### Factory Default
There are two ways to factory default a Renos-based system:
1. **Local - single unit overwrite**: Use a USB cable to connect the USB port to the service port for the factory default.
2. **Local - complete system factory default**: Execute this during the configuration wizard.

### System ID
You need the System ID to set up a Device Management system. The firmware version is displayed in the top right corner of the configuration wizard. Clicking on the firmware version shows a pop-up with the System ID during the configuration.

patterns: How can I service the installation after it's completed?
What is Device Management in Nedap systems?
What functionalities does the Device Management platform provide?
How can I monitor the iSense systems locally?
responses: Once the installation is complete, it can be serviced via Nedap Device Management. Monitoring options are also available locally using SNMP.

### Device Management
Nedap Retail systems can connect to the online Device Management platform to manage systems remotely and ensure optimal global performance. The platform offers the following main functions:
1. **Monitoring**: Critical system parameters are monitored 24/7. Alerts are generated if there are issues.
2. **Remote Service**: Authorized Nedap-certified engineers can access the system for configuration changes.
3. **Firmware Update**: Engineers can install new firmware remotely using the Device Management website.
4. **Data Collection**: Events per system are tracked for analytics reporting.
5. **Sleep mode**: Helps conserve energy during non-operational hours as per the configured schedule.
For more details about network information, please refer to the document on the portal.

### SNMP
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) is available for local monitoring of iSense systems. For instance:
- If one or more Renos units are unreachable.
- If the system is connected to Device Management.
You can access the SNMP using the URL format: `http://<ip address of the system>/snmp`, e.g., `http://192.168.133.1/snm` when connected to the USB service port.

patterns: What should I do if the red LED on the Renos unit is on?
Why is the red LED on the Renos unit blinking?
What if the green LED on the Renos unit is off?
How do I troubleshoot the RFID reader issue?
responses:
### Symptoms and Solutions
1. **Red LED (3) on a Renos unit is ON**:
   - **Cause**: The current drawn out of the OUT port is too low.
   - **Solution**: Verify whether the cabling length in the system satisfies the requirements posed earlier in this document.
   - **Cause**: The connectors of the Ethernet cable at the OUT port of the Renos unit are not mated properly.
   - **Solution**: Check the Ethernet cable at the OUT port of the Renos unit with an Ethernet cable tester.

2. **Red LED (3) on a Renos unit is BLINKING**:
   - **Cause**: The current drawn out of the Renos unit's OUT port is too high.
   - **Solution**: Verify the number of Renos units and add-ons connected to the Power Inserters with the table in this document.
   - **Cause**: A short circuit in the cabling leaves this Renos unit's OUT port.
   - **Solution**: Check the Ethernet cable at the OUT port of the Renos unit with an Ethernet cable tester.

3. **Green LED (1) on a Renos unit is OFF**:
   - **Cause**: There is an issue in the cabling between those units.
   - **Solution**: Check Ethernet cabling with an Ethernet cable tester.

4. **Red LED (3) on the RFID reader is ON**:
   - **Cause**: The RFID reader is having trouble starting to read.
   - **Solution**: Log in to the Renos configuration interface to see the exact error.

patterns: What do I do if I can't access the configuration web interface?
Why is the configuration not starting on the Renos unit?
How can I fix cabling errors during configuration?
What if my RFID is configured incorrectly?
responses:
### Symptoms and Solutions
1. **Cannot access the configuration web interface**:
   - **Cause**: The Renos unit has not started yet.
   - **Solution**: Verify the green "firmware running" LED on the Renos unit (6). If this LED is not on, verify the system has power or wait five minutes and try again.

2. **Mini USB cable not attached to Renos unit and laptop**:
   - **Solution**: Attach the cable to the Renos unit and laptop.

3. **Driver not installed**:
   - **Solution**: On Windows 7 and older, you need to manually install a driver to support Renos.

4. **WAN access port is closed**:
   - **Cause**: The WAN access port will be 'closed' for internal network traffic during configuration.
   - **Solution**: If you combine two systems later, this needs to be re-opened.

5. **Cabling error**:
   - **Solution**: Please check all Ethernet cabling with an Ethernet cable tester.

6. **Not all Power Inserters are powered**:
   - **Cause**: Some Renos units are not fully started.
   - **Solution**: Verify the green "firmware running" LED on the Renos unit (6). If this LED is not on, verify the system has power, or wait five minutes and try again.

7. **Three LEDs (4, 5, and 6) are on, indicating a firmware failure**:
   - **Solution**: Something might have gone wrong with a firmware update.

8. **Gates positioned incorrectly**:
   - **Solution**: Check the "Orientation of products" section in the manual and correct the orientation of the gates.

patterns: What is CE WEEE?
What are the requirements under Directive 2002/96/EC?
How is electrical equipment marked for CE WEEE compliance?
responses:
### CE WEEE Information
This European Standard specifies a marking:
1. Of electrical and electronic equipment following Article 11(2) of Directive 2002/96/EC (WEEE). This is in addition to the marking requirement in Article 10(3) of this Directive, which requires producers to mark electrical and electronic equipment put on the market after 13 August 2005 with a 'crossed-out wheeled bin' symbol.

2. It applies to electrical and electronic equipment falling under Annex IA of Directive 2002/96/EC, provided the equipment concerned is not part of another type of equipment that does not fall within the scope of this Directive. ### About Nedap
Together, we make merchandise simply available.

At Nedap, we believe in 'Technology for Life'. Nedap Retail enables retailers to serve their customers better. Using technology, we allow for perfect inventory visibility, total control, no waste, and no losses.

### Our Vision for Inventory Visibility
Today, established retailers need more information about where their items are. Without this knowledge, providing an omnichannel experience leads to heavy overstocking, waste, and eroding margins. Solving this requires a fundamental change in the retailers' supply chain and information systems.

Our mission is to simplify the process of ensuring that retailers always have the right products available at the right place and time.

We achieve this by giving retailers perfect inventory visibility for a seamless shopping experience. This way, retailers can meet the changing consumer needs while remaining profitable.

Nedap works with the largest and most successful retailers in the world. We take complete ownership of our projects—failure is never an option. A unique combination of the best technology and industry teams at Nedap Retail achieves this.

Nedap solutions are built upon 45 years of global experience, market expertise, and close cooperation with leading retailers. A flexible network of certified partners worldwide supports our worldwide operations. Nedap systems are future-proof (RFID-ready), cost-efficient, and Eco-friendly. Our mission is to ensure retailers' customers maintain the best shopping experience while we help retailers protect their profits.

### Contact
If you need further details or help preparing, executing, or servicing an installation, please contact our support team at support-retail@nedap.com.

Suggestions for improving our products and documentation are much appreciated.
